Award.AwardTitle: The molecular mechanisms by which novel pathogens emerge
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will investigate the mechanisms by which pathogens evolve new host ranges; despite the direct relevance of host-range evolution to wildlife disease, agriculture, and human health, these mechanisms are still poorly understood. The common, ecologically important and widely studied insect-pathogenic fungus Metarhizium is an ideal model for studying the evolution of pathogens, pathogenesis and infectious disease. Closely related strains of these fungi have independently evolved as either broad-spectrum generalists (infecting a broad range of insects) or as specialists with narrow, specific host ranges (with particular strains infecting only locusts, grasshoppers, scarab beetles, or other particular insect groups). Some of the generalist insect pathogens also form beneficial associations with plant roots. Atlases of genomic diversity and gene expression will be assembled for four generalist and seven specialist Metarhizium strains, and coupled with bioinformatic analysis and hypothesis-driven experiments on select candidate genes, to determine: 1) the number, nature and networking of genes that regulate and execute infection processes; 2) the factors controlling virulence, host-range specificity and host-switching; 3) key targets for engineering alterations of pathogen performance for environmentally benign management of insect pests, and 4) development of a tractable model for studying mutation rates over evolutionary time. The focus of this research on the genetic basis of transitions between specialist and generalist host ranges will provide a much-needed model for understanding the evolution of new diseases. Finally, this project is excellent for research training as it exposes students to genomics, bioinformatics, molecular biology, microbiology, microscopy and fundamental scientific principles of host-pathogen biology and evolution. In addition to training a postdoctoral associate and two graduate students, this study will provide research opportunities for undergraduate students, including six from underrepresented groups; research activities will also be used to develop lesson plans for various classroom projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In spite of being of great concern to human health and the management of plants and animals, the mechanisms facilitating how pathogens select hosts and switch between hosts remain largely unknown. The goal of the project was to examine the mechanisms by which novel pathogens emerge. To this end we sequenced multiple genomes to look at the evolution of narrow versus broad host range variation in species of the ubiquitous insect pathogen Metarhizium.

Our genomic study design included calculation of mutation frequencies, phylogenetic estimation of time points of lineage diversification as the fungi adapted to different hosts, and analysis of known insect virulence and plant-associated genes to obtain a wide-ranging depiction of mutability and adaptation to parasitism (insect hosts) and mutualism (plant associations).

Our data has contributed to a much better understanding of trends in pathogen evolution, genome dynamics and how databases of related genomes can contribute to microevolutiony research. We used genomic comparisons of the diverged Metarhizium strains to provide a unique dataset for uncovering the mechanisms, direction and intensity of natural selection in eukaryotic pathogens. In particular, we identified gene loss/gain/divergence correlated with adaptations to specific hosts/different plant associations, and identified the underlying regulatory, metabolic and biosynthetic differences that define host preferences. Having multiple closely related Metarhizium genomes allowed directional selection to be inferred in closely related specialist narrow host range and generalist broad strains, and so determine whether there are consistent features associated with each lifestyle, allowing characterization of heterogeneity in processes of genomic evolution, and providing a time scale at which things happen. This has a major impact in identifying targets of selection, what evolutionary forces are at play, what the strength of selection is, and whether selection has been acting in the more or less recent past.

In terms of broader impacts, the PI and students have made brochures, posters and animations, and have given talks on topics related to the research to organizations of citizen scientists and to schools. The PI has intergrated genomic data sets from this project into undergraduate genetics classes. The project has also been integrated into the annual UMD open day (which has ~35,000 visitors) in the form of a booth on the universities central mall that showed posters and exhibits of infected insects (from giant cockroaches to mosquitoes) and the plant growth promoting effects of Metarhizium and other fungi. Students were involved in organizing this event and attended with the PI. The PI presents results in a MOOC on the Coursera platform that to date has had 93,000 students.
